Reviews.Content: Great Location!!! ProsThis a nice, quaint hotel. The staff was nice and helpful. Great location between Bourbon and Royal in the French Quarter. ConsWhile we were there we found out they are closing as of 12-01-08. Hopefully someone will buy this lovely old property and reopen it.
Reviews.Author: SGRIERSON

Reviews.Content: Not so suite #9 Not so suite#9 was introduced into our lives in July2008 and leaves us wondering how a couple of locals could have been duped into staying at this garbage substation. Firstly, there was this sense of southern hospitality when the bellman was seen admiring my wife carrying 20 pieces of luggage by herself. After check-in, we squeezed through the door fit for a ten year old and plunged into the bed never to return. In all fairness, some people like a bed that swallows them whole. After peeling from the abyss, we began investigating what other exciting features this room may have to offer. Highlights such as previously owned shampoo bottles, flame throwing air conditioner (1970's window unit), and stained sheets reminded us of how lucky we were to be enjoying the weekend in the heart of the quarter. After we realized alcohol couldn't even help this room, we decided to check into the Omni Orleans at 4am and cursed for not doing it sooner. This review has been edited so that it may be presented to the public!
Reviews.Author: ConcernedLocal

Reviews.Content: Great Little Hotel We just loved this nice little hotel.Location is excellent along Toulouse, halfway between Bourbon and Royal. Everything (bars, famous restaurants, shops) is within a couple blocks. We stayed in Room 15 and had a sitting room on street side and bedroom on courtyard side. Bedroom had French doors that opened to courtyard. At night it was quiet for sleeping and in the late morning we would leave the doors open to listen to jazz music from the adjacent restaurant. Furnishings are basic but rustic and fit in well with the overall d茅cor of the hotel as well as your location.Customer service is okay. The staff is helpful as long as you ask, but don鈥檛 expect them to greet you or volunteer help.You are paying for a nice room in an excellent location. This is a 3-star hotel and the service and furnishings are commensurate with its star rating. Don鈥檛 go expecting 5-star service and you won鈥檛 be disappointed.
Reviews.Author: nyc.tula_couple

Reviews.Content: Living in the Quarter Although the property is not up to date in every way, staying here is like living in the French Quarter of New Orleans. We loved the private courtyards, amazing pool, great service, etc. One of us did not love the noise at night, but of course, this is part of living in the Quarter! This is our 6th or 7th time in New Orleans, and our most intimate stay to date.
Reviews.Author: wpw2008

Reviews.Content: Best place to stay in New Orleans! I've visited the Maison de Ville a few times and always had a wonderful experience. Staying at the main house or at the Audubon Cottages is one of the best parts of my trip to New Orleans. The friendly staff, beautiful architecture, lush courtyards and traditional New Orleans decor are perfect. I always recommend the Maison de Ville to friends and associates who are planning a visit to the crescent city and have been thanked by everyone who took the advise.
Reviews.Author: userCalifornia

Reviews.Content: OK not terrific The location is great - just off Bourbon street right in the French Quarter. And quiet enough though that you can sleep.The staff were very friendly and personable.Nice bed, thick towels and robes.Beautiful courtyard and atmospheric hotel. You feel the history of the place.Now for the minuses: We booked a courtyard room and got a room which opened out to a wall. The staff quickly changed our room when we notified them of this and we got a smaller room in the main house but which had a lovely balcony to the courtyard. The room is fairly small and cramped though. The bathroom was bigger, but the toilet didn't work. Every time you wanted to flush, you had to reach into the water tank and jiggle something. We first told the staff about it and they fixed it right away. The second time it happened, they didn't fix it and we had to reach into the water tank everytime we wanted to flush the toilet.Also found stray hair in the bathtub.I would say it's an OK place to stay, but probably wouldn't come back.
Reviews.Author: andrewchurchill

Reviews.Content: Wonderful and Relaxing Mardi Gras Although my stay was brief this time at the Maison Deville it was just as great as I expected and hoped for. My friends and I spend Lundi Gras in Room 15. The attic room was wonderful and very quiet. The balcony that overlooked the courtyard and French Quarter roofline was better than I expected. As usual the staff was wonderful (especially Vicky) and I am already planning my next visit. Thanks again to the whole staff!
Reviews.Author: Nolagirl70002

Reviews.Content: Relaxing Weekend With a Surprise My fiance and I recently spent the weekend in cottage #2, and had a nice relaxing experience. I never knew we could relax and feel as though we were on vacation in the city we live in. We were both upset to leave when it came time to return to our real home. The rooms are large and the jacuzzi bathtub is sooooo relaxing. The cottage is nicely tucked off from the quarter, and with a short walk you can walk into the quarter night life. I truley enjoyed how dark the rooms stayed in the morning....no sunshine in your eyes after a night on the town hahahaha!!! We also had a pleasent tease (twice) from the other guest how reside on location. Not to spooky but added a little mystery and adventure to our weekend. I think it was the ghostly kids who reside there. We both recommend the cottages to everyone, and can't wait until we can do it again!!!
Reviews.Author: swollmonson

Reviews.Content: Not So Great Over the years my husband and I have stayed at Hotel Maison De Ville a number of times. I agree with the negative reviews. At first you may be enchanted with the veneer of elegance, so to speak, but when you scratch just below the surface, well, it's pretty grubby. The staff wasn't what I would call exceptionally customer-friendly, either. On one ttrip Maison De Ville was booked, so we tried a bed and breakfast in the Esplanade Ridge area. We were stunned at the difference - beautiful, spotless rooms, gourmet (hot) breakfasts, and exceptional amenities and service. All for about 1/3 the cost of the Maison. We never again stayed at Maison De Ville.
Reviews.Author: Ravenwilde

Reviews.Content: High Price; Serious Problems I鈥檇 wanted to stay at this property for years, given the stellar reviews and reputation, and that鈥檚 why we were so terribly disappointed. 鈥淒rop off,鈥?as a previous reviewed notes, is not only bad 鈥?it鈥檚 a nightmare. I circled the entire French Quarter 4 times before the lone attendant arrived to shoo traffic around my car while I straddled the curb to check in. He had been unavailable because of the 鈥渃ommute鈥?between the main property and the Cottages where I was staying. After I checked in, he navigated my car another lap around the Quarter until we arrived at the Audubon Cottages, again straddling the curb so I could off-load. There, just after dark, was a staff member, lurking in the dark in the sitting room area of the Cottage. One look at me, and he quickly slunk off into the night 鈥?aware that he had violated the most important rule in all hoteldom 鈥?staffs do not spend time in the room unless doing work. Then the real nightmare began. The floor of the first bedroom had stains from patrons vomiting (something one expects on Bourbon Street from the strollers there, but not in one鈥檚 room), and throughout our stay no one bothered to vacuum the bobbie pins and other debris left on the floor by previous occupants. In one of the 2 bathrooms, the toilet leaked onto the floor, then on our last day it simply stopped flushing. The flat-screen TV (spoken of glowingly in other reviews) was off kilter, so one watched garbled pictures. The wireless Internet service 鈥渢hroughout the property鈥?never did work 鈥?so the first morning, I trekked over to the main property, but the Internet service there, having failed the night before, was likewise out of order (so I ended up trudging down the block to a dingy Internet caf茅). So much for enjoying a leisurely morning coffee in my room 鈥?I ended up spending more time at the Internet caf茅 than at the Maison de Ville! New Orleans is famous for its decadence, but the two jardini猫res on either side of the door to our cottage contained limp, dead plants which failed to revive despite my watering them (moral: The staff is not being supervised, and the management is not touring the property often enough to notice the problems). The much-vaunted 鈥渇irst swimming pool in the Quarter鈥?was ice cold, and no one seemed interested in a polar bear plunge throughout our stay. The 鈥渁ntique鈥?furniture is just old, care-worn stuff 鈥?and the pictures of historical English figures (Oliver Cromwell and Sarah Churchill in our Cottage) would have given traditional New Orleanians fits. When I complained to the Manager about the ongoing lack of Internet service, I was given a much-pained look and offered a credit on my bill for the cost of the Internet caf茅 charges. In the ensuing verbal duel I told her that, for over $600 a night (base charge of $539, plus the confiscatory state and local taxes), I was expecting basic amenities to be in place and workable 鈥?which simply isn鈥檛 the case with this property. Recommendation: This is not a hotel; it is a rather poorly maintained guest house whose staff seems a bit out of control; do not expect high standards of service or hygiene; and for the same neighborhood and much lower prices, I highly recommend the Olivier House Hotel which, interestingly enough, constitutes one contiguous property between the 2 Maison de Ville 鈥渃ommutable properties, but it has much more spacious, interesting, and well maintained rooms and suites. (In fact, after several attempts to get dining and other information out of the Maison de Ville staff, I started going into the Olivier where the staff was much more responsive and knowledgeable.) Summary: For the price, stay at the Windsor Court or the Ritz; for the in-the-Quarter guest house experience, stay at the Olivier.
Reviews.Author: stewartsdad

Reviews.Content: Fantastic Hotel I've lived in New Orleans for several years and been back a number of times since so I was pretty familiar with the hotel scene when I was booking for this trip. I now live in NYC, so I wasn't really interested in the big box type hotel (no Ritz or Windsor Court) and wanted to try a good BB or smaller hotel with more character - preferably in or near the Quarter. Also, was planning on getting engaged on this trip, so the place also needed to be really nice, romantic, have a good level of service, amenities, etc. Ended up making a decision between the Soniat House, Maison de Ville, House on Bayou Road and Maison Perrier. Ended up taking Maison de Ville primarily based on location and then Trip Advisor reviews. First of all, the place couldn't be in a better location if you want to be in the Quarter. A block off Bourbon, but still quiet enough if you take a room on the courtyard. Luaggage drop off is a pain since the street is narrow and one way, but the main building is fantastic - the courtyard is off the charts. Gary at the front dest was a huge help with everything and a great guy. We actually stayed in Audubon Cottage #1 which is about a block away on Dauphine. The cottages are totally secluded and surround what's said to be the oldest swimming pool in the Quarter. Our place shared a huge patio and fountain with Cottage #7. The place had two bedrooms, two large bathrooms, a large living area, a ton of antique furniture and was really one of the most unique places I've ever stayed in the US. Fiance is a high-end event planner and she said the same. Large bay doors open out of the living room onto the patio and we would eat our great breakfast in the morning listening to birds and the fountain. Service was good and amenities are nice - full wireless, flat screen TV's. I think there is a certain trade-off to staying in this kind of place v. a larger hotel, meaning that if I was in town for a night on business, I'd probably stick to the CBD since it's a little easier to get in and out (if you have a car, parking is offsite at the Ramada and $30/ day - bellman will grab your car in about 5 minutes through), but otherwise, I'd reccomend this as one of the better hotels in the country.
Reviews.Author: bogginla

Reviews.Content: Damp room The hotel is lovely situated in the French Quarter. The staff is friendly, courteous and service minded. They are more than happy to make dinner/ luncheon reservations for you or give you advice on where to go or what to see in the Crescent City.However, I stayed in a room with entrance from the courtyard (no 10). The room was way to damp and the air conditioner kept me awake most of the night. I tried to change room, but the hotel was full. Furthermore, the bathroom floor was dirty. The 8 towels were changed once a day (very good) and the sheets once during my 3 nights-stay. Breakfast is nice- take it on the balcony or in the courtyard. A friend had a room upstairs, which was absolutely charming (nr 4), with a canopy bed and Toile de Jouy hangings, so I'm certain the hotel is worth its 175 dollars/ night/ single room. Do stay at Hotel Maison de Ville while visiting New Orleans, but stay away from the courtyard rooms! Tip: eat lunch at Bayona, Commander's Palace, Bourbon House. Have coffee and beignets at Caf茅 du monde. Have an exotic brunch at Brennan's on Royal Street (order the flamb茅ed bananas). Do vist Faulkner House Book Shop and take the Katrina Tour. You won't regret it!And avoid Bourbon Street, it is a disgrace-
Reviews.Author: Vive

Reviews.Content: Fantastic staff and hotel! Perfect place to stay for our first trip to New Orleans. The hotel is close to everything, but our room over the courtyard was quiet enough that nothing from Bourbon Street bothered us. The staff on site was fantastic (thanks Chad!!)--gave lots of good ideas and was always available for questions or chatting. Breakfast in the courtyard was a great way to start the day. Yes, the rooms are small, but in a historic setting, we expected that. However, we felt very comfortable in the charming room, and just moved out to the balcony or down to the courtyard if we needed additional room to stretch out. We can't wait to return. Chuck and Sue West Milford NJ
Reviews.Author: NJtraveler2007

Reviews.Content: Fabulous (as always) We stayed at the Maison de Ville just 4wks prior to Katrina, and have not had the opportunity to return until now. We have always loved the city and its citizens and watching the horror of Katrina broke my heart. I applaud the citizens who have returned to their much loved city and the tourist and business travelers who are also giving their support by returning. The Maison de Ville has definitely returned to it's pre-K standards!! We have stayed at many properties in the Quarter thru the years, but once we found the Maison de Ville, we have stayed no where else. The ambiance and staff are simply unbeatable! This is a two hundred year old home - and it wears its age well. This is a beautiful and charmimg small historic hotel and after one night, you feel as if you live there. Nothing is better than walking thru your floor to ceiling bedroom window to have coffee and pastries on your balcony ,watching the Quarter wake up. The courtyard is just as beautiful and we really enjoyed sitting out in the evening,sipping wine or a beer, and hearing the jazz float in from the Court of Two Sisters courtyard next door. The welcoming and so helpful staff are always near by to assist in whatever way you may need them, yet they are so unobtrusive that you forget they are there. We loved our stay there, and I have never seen the Quarter and especially Bourbon look so clean. Everyone we met were so grateful to have us visit. The Quarter is back to normal, and with the exception of the St. Charles Streetcar still not fully functional, the Garden District, CBD, and Wharehouse districts were also fully functional. You can see the damage if you look, and the empty slabs and shattered houses of the 9th ward, East New Orleans, and the Lakeview area stand as testaments to the tragedy that befell this beautiful city and shattered the lives of so many of its citizens. They are fighting to bring their city and their lives back to normal. Show your support and come on down. You won't regret it - and a stay at the Maison de Ville will only enhance your visit!!!!!
Reviews.Author: houtxtraveler

Reviews.Content: Great place that needs a deep cleaning       Ansicht vom Pool
Reviews.Author: yeahthatsright

Reviews.Content: The Best New Orleans Hotel We have been to New Orleans many times and this was the best experience yet! This hotel has only 14 rooms and is on the historic registry so you have to expect fairly small rooms and thin walls. But, this is New Orleans and who stays in their room anyway! That is far outweighed by the atmosphere and the five star service. We were pampered as if we were staying at five star resort. Your continental breakfast is served each morning on a silver tray with a rose at the exact time you specify. You may have it privately in your room or served in the courtyard outside your room with live jazz filtering in from the Court of the Two Sisters that adjoins the hotel. It is only a few steps from Bourbon Street - yet you never hear the sounds at all. The location is only a few blocks from all the other sites such as the French Market, the Riverwalk, Harrah's, etc. The people at the front desk will make sure you have every possible thing you need. We could not have asked for a more romantic anniversary trip and will definitely stay here again. New Orleans is back! Come on down!
Reviews.Author: arkansastraveler3

Reviews.Content: One of my favorite hotels, and I can't wait to return!       More pics of Room 17
Reviews.Author: FreddieBSeattle

Reviews.Content: Flummoxed My husband and I had always wanted to stay at the Audubon Cottages at the Maison de Ville and were initially delighted with our charming little cottage. In fact, we were so smitten that we tried to overlook the neglected garden, the unmopped bathroom floor, the grimy sink and the dusty carpets. At first, we chalked up the irregular turndowns, the sullen looks from groundskeepers, the progressively (and outrageously) unclean bathroom, the sheets that were rarely, if ever, changed, to post-Katrina malaise, but we stayed at our cottage several days, and it became increasingly difficult to justify the blatant indifference to performing the most basic housekeeping tasks. Really the only duties we could count on to be completed on a daily basis were the prompt delivery of our breakfast and a fresh supply of towels.We still love the place and would like to return some day, but it makes us sad to see such a magical spot so mismanaged and abused. In the future we hope that the cottages will be given the respect and attention that they deserve.
Reviews.Author: Walkonby

Reviews.Content: Wonderful time at Maison de Ville       the courtyard
Reviews.Author: bbihler

Reviews.Content: Questionable Ranking Booked two rooms at the Maison de Ville based on the popularity rating on Trip Advisor. This old hotel is not worthy of such a high mark. All of the established French Quarter hotels that I have stayed at offer superior accommodations. The Prince Conti, St. Marie, Place de Arms, Maison du Puy are better choices in the Quarter.
Reviews.Author: jeterbug

Reviews.Content: French Quarter retreat We stayed at Maison De Ville 2 nights 9/25-9/27. The bed was comfortable, the continental breakfast served where and when you pick was great. The location was excellent, 1/2 block from Bourbon Street.. The bell man was very helpful, as parking was a pain. We received a parking ticket as the only was to unload is to stop in the middle of the street and have everyone wait for you. Of course, we didn't want to do that, but live and learn. It would have been helpful, if there were better instructions on this. It is $30/day for parking, which we knew from the website. They also have unlimited long distance phone service and Inernet access. We happened to be in town for the Saints Monday night football game. As noisey as it was on the streets, it was quiet in the hotel.
Reviews.Author: dalebonnie

Reviews.Content: welcome retreat in a torn city I arrived in New Orleans expecting the worst. I found, instead, a sanctuary in the French quarter. The Maison exceeded all expectations in providing a safe, comfortable home-like environment . The staff was gracious and helpful. Brian, the concierge, went beyond the call in providing restaurant and tour information and arranging all the reservations. His attention to my needs is greatly appreciated. Can't wait to go back!
Reviews.Author: georgiatrip

Reviews.Content: Paid for location not quality of hotel My boyfriend and I wanted to visit New Orleans for the weekend of August 11-13th. I expected this hotel to be in an excellent location and from the reviews I expected it to be above average. Boy, were we disappointed. First in all fairness, I must say the location was really great..however the street it's located on is narrow and we had to actually stop traffic to have someone park our car because there wasn't any place for us to park ourselves. Parking by the way is $30/day.We stayed in Room #9 which is on the ground floor and is accessible through the courtyard. The courtyard was nice and pretty although they did had several empty flower containers and even some dead vegetation...I just thought well maybe it's hard to get a landscaper these days. When we opened the door to our room....it was humid and very musty....still I thought maybe once the air conditioner stayed on for a while...it would get better. The next thing I noticed was that the room was very dark and I'm talking like a cave. There were no over head lights, just two nightstand lights. At this point I was getting a little let down....till I walked into the bathroom..Come to find out only one light bulb was working. Sure everything was marble and not bad fixtures but I could barely see....the fan, overhead light and one light bulb above the sink were all either burned out or not working. We did have a flat screen tv but it really didn't matter at this point. Did I happen to mention that the walls were wood paneling-which also made the room very dark. We decided to just stick it out...and stay there...since we had no idea if there would be vacancies else where since the APA convention was in town. The smell did eventually go away ...or maybe we just got used to it...but later that evening while taking off my makeup I noticed something out of the corner of my eye...yep you guessed it ...a roach...a live one...yuk....well I got rid of the roach and the next day...my boyfriend and I found another big live one ...gross....the good points for this hotel were that it has a great location, nice tv and a nice bed but the room had roaches, was extremely dark and wasn't all that clean. So there you have it....Would I recommend this hotel....well not room #9 maybe the other rooms are better. I know we won't be going back.--Hope this helps ...Good Luck!
Reviews.Author: rosepetal

Reviews.Content: Perfect setting, great staff, Absolutely loved this hotel Date: July 24, 2006We just returned from a three day weekend in the French Quarter for my birthday celebration. We spent two nights at this hotel in Room #6. Upon arrival, Brian, helped us with dinning reservations during our stay. He was so helpful and knowledgeable. I loved his insight into where to dine and at what time of day. Brian was great, I just wish we had seen him again during our stay, but he must just work during the week. Tina took over where Brian left off and was there to help and answer questions all during the weekend with a very pleasant smile. I loved the quaintness of this hotel. Because of the size, the staff all know you and call you by name as you come and go during the day. Makes you feel very special and pampered!We loved so many things about this hotel. Our room was great. We were upstairs on the corner overlooking the courtyard. Albert brought our complimentary breakfast and newspaper each morning to the courtyard where we had the best fresh baked croissants, a muffin, orange juice, and coffee all on a silver tray with a fresh rose. Breakfast in the courtyard is so peacful listing to the fountain and watching the two big turtles swim around. The bed was so soft. The matress was down and so were the pillows and the comforter. It was like a little piece of heaven. We enjoyed the feel of staying in a place with so much history while watching the British Open on a flat screen television. A nice touch to a very historical room. Although this hotel is only a half a block off Bourbon Street it is amazing that the minute you enter the front door, all the noise is gone. We never heard the noise of Bourbon Street. The location of this hotel is excellent for sightseeing and enjoying the party on Bourbon Street. We loved the afternoon port wine and sherry available for their guests. A nice way to unwind from the day and relax before dinner. We did get a key from Tina and go over and look at the cottages and the swimming pool about a block away that are also part of this hotel. They are hidden away and share a common courtyard of their own. This will probably be our choice next time we stay at Maison de Ville. I have been to the quarter many times before and have stayed in many of the high rise hotels, but I will return to Maison de Ville from now on. I can't say enough good things about this hotel, we loved our stay and will never stay anywhere else when we come to the quarter.
Reviews.Author: Modaud

Reviews.Content: like being in europe My daugher and I visited the cresent city for the first time since the hurricane. I lived there in the 80's and wanted to see the city for myself. We loved the Maison de ville. We have traveled in Europe and enjoy the quaintness of small BB's. This is the perfect place to avoid large hotel crowds. Perfect for walking the quarter, french market and canel street if you wish. Just step inside and Brian will take care of everything. Not only is he pleasent to visit with, but has great knowledge of all restaurants and activities. We had a room off the courtyard, small, but beautiful. You can pay more and have a larger room. For the two of us...this was perfect. Love the duvets on the bed and high ceilings. We had the AC on and it was very quiet. They also serve port and wine in the evenings. Nice touch. We enjoyed breakfast on the patio and although it was July, it was pleasent. If you want small, quaint and personal...this is the place for you. My regards to Brian and all the staff.
Reviews.Author: Robin509

Reviews.Content: Lovely place, hospitable staff.. A couple of blocks from the Bourbon St, this is a perfect place to be.You will definately get more than what you pay for your room..The staff is so hospitable  we very much enjoyed the complimentary in-room breakfast.We certainly recommend this place  will come back to stay there again.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Maison de Ville: It's time to come back My wife and I visit family near New Orleans regularly, and have loved staying here a couple of times a year for several years now. We had to cancel a trip last October because of Katrina, and we were not sure when it would be OK to visit New Orleans again. We checked closely, and went the last week of April. Well, we are so glad we did. The hotel is completely shipshape. No sign of water damage whatsoever. The Bistro at Maison de Ville is likewise. All your favorite people are there: Brian, Greg, Patrick, and HollyBrian at the Bistro. Rates are down, and rooms that are usually booked a year in advance are much easier to get than usual just because the word isn't out. For those of you who have never stayed at the Maison de Ville, this little gem is a well-kept but widely known secret. It is small, right off Boubon Street, European style, and by far the most romantic hotel in the Vieux Carre. It has one of those courtyards that tourists hear about but very few ever get to see. Top-notch French-style continental breakfast is served on your balcony, in the courtyard, or in your room (your preference) on a silver tray with a rose and a newspaper daily until noon (included in daily rate). The Bistro, located next door, also is less widely known because it is small, but the food there is matched only by the two or three top restaurants in the city and surpassed by none.The Quarter is actually in fine shape. If you like the music or dancing, it seems the businesses in the quarter are actually trying harder to please in order to attract people back. Crowds are a bit light, especially midweek (a good thing?), but even midweek there are lots of live bands playing lots of music. On the weekends the Quarter fills up, especially with people from all over the region who can drive to town. Most of the top restaurants have reopened; if it's the food that brings you back, you will have no problem finding your favorites. We had our usual super bangup time. Maybe a little bit better than usual. Besides, we think we should help our friends in need, and what they need is visitors. N'Awlins is reknowned above all for its hospitality. Here is a chance to return that favor while enjoying your vacation. Hey, y'all. It's time to come back.
Reviews.Author: fanandsteve

Reviews.Content: Fabulous Find, Obscenely Comfortable This is the type of hotel you hope to find when you vist a place like the French Quarter. For us during the madness of the Jazz Fest, it was an oasis from the noise and movement and excitement. It is the type of hotel you swear you will keep a secret until the day you die, yet, at the same time, you find yourself sharing it with your aunt, your friend at work, your neighboor, kicking yourself all the while because, soon, someone will be sitting having a drink on *your* balcony and sleeping in *your* bed. Here are some details to make your mouth water.Location: Right where you want to be, just off of Bourbon Street. Far away enough from the party in the street, but close enough to walk right into it.Breakfast: You can have the continental breakfast brought to your room. We had ours in the courtyard, which was a cool, flower-draped place, with greenery tumbling over the walls. They brought us fresh orange juice, hot coffee, croissants fresh from the oven, and sweet rolls. With plenty of butter and cream and jam to go with, and with those weather-softened bricks under our bare feet, we swore that we were all moving to the French Quarter! The courtyard had a lovely fountain, that was quiet and gentle, with interesting balconies, all was swept and clean and soothing.Bedrooms: I could have sworn we had the nicest, the *best* room in the whole place. After all, it had an enourmous bed, and a balcony that overlooked Toulouse Street and one of those cool windows you push up far enough to where you can just walk right out onto the balcony. Then I got a peek at some of the other rooms and realized they were *all* like that, with special touches that could make you feel you were in some unique place undiscovered by anyone else. The bed? Oh, man. Obscene. A grand, king sized bed designed to make you want to get out of it just so you could get back into it. There was first a pillow-top mattress. On top of that was a feather padding, about two inches thick. On top of that was a batting to give even more cushion. Then this was covered by 300 count clean white sheets, and there was about ninety-eleven (six!) pillows so there was no need to be stingy or even share.Decor: This hotel, like many others, suffered during Katrina. However, within the walls of the hotel, of the hurricane I found no sign. The hotel was one of the last to open this season, and when I asked why, I found out that it was because they wanted it to be just exactly like it was. All the furniture and stuff was taken out and cleaned. The walls were dried and cleaned of mold and then repainted in those soft hues so suitable to the French Quarter. The floors shined as though they had been lovingly polished by hand for hours. The bannisters gleamed, the windows were spotless. The whole place smelled clean and fresh. The furniture was what it should be, a collection of slightly Victorian, slightly French with dark polished wood carved in graceful curves.Brian: The man in charge. The concierge. He took care of so many things for us while we were there, and seemed to be available whenever we needed him. When we arrived at the hotel, and went too far in the car down the street, Brian sent someone out to park the car for my dad, so that he did not have to sit in the heat to wait to go around the block in the stand-still traffic. They took our luggage right up to our rooms, and Brian delt with the cumbersome oxygen tanks that my dad has to travel with. Then Brian gave me directions to just the right bar to take my neice to get a drink, and answered our questions about the hotel and its history. He's been with the hotel for at least 20 years and seemed to really enjoy his job.Overall Rating: Excellent! I have a thing for old buildings that are kept up with love and respect. This hotel retains the charm and texture of its history, and while there is a computer in the lobby for you to use, it is arranged so that you almost don't see it sitting there amongst the small side table, the victorian couch, and the standing room screen. The plants. The rugs. The gleaming floor. You get the picture. Sure, if you want someplace new you can find plenty of new, sparkling hotels on the edge of the FQ that have wall to wall carpets and elevators and stuff like that. But if you're coming to the French Quarter to get a little texture and charm and something real, then why on earth would you stay anyplace else? All the rooms are unique, and it staying there is more like visiting your Aunt Louise, who has a thing for French windows and can afford the staff to keep up that floor and deliver your croissants while they are still warm. The only thing you will regret is that you don't live there yourself.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Maison de Ville I had the pleasure of staying at this hotel in April of 06. The hotel is in perfect shape after the hurricane. The rooms have been redone and offer all the ammenities one would want in a hotel. The staff was far and away the most cordial and helpful of any hotel I have stayed in .....the location is perfect. Visit New Orleans and definitely stay here.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Fabulous recovery I have stayed at this hotel a number of times before Katrina and, there was no doubt, I would stay there again when bringing a friend to NOLA for the first time. The hotel suffered some damage, but has recovered beautifully! It is every bit as charming as it always was, and the forced renovation has put all new FABULOUS matresses and other furnishings in the guest rooms. But, the best part of this establishment is the staff held together by Vicky who greets them each morning with a hug. The gorgeous courtyard is still the site of terrific French breakfasts and The Bistro restaurant is tops. The people of New Orleans are very grateful to see tourists--the restaurants (the most important aspect of the city) are as outrageous as ever. We had a ball and have vowed to return every 6 months to let the folks know we are behind them--THEY NEED US--THEY NEED YOU!
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Great visit Stayed at the Maison for my wife's 40th birthday. This was our first trip to New Orleans and did not know what to expect post-Katrina. The staff was first rate, particularly Jeffrey and Brian at the front desk. They were very accomodating and gracious. Due to what appeared to be short staffing, they filled many roles with graciousness and good humor. Unfortunately, these two had to have time off and thier replacements were not in the same league. We asked to visit the Audobon cottages for a swim and to explore. When we got there,even though staff were actively renovating, the GM, Vicky, took the time to show us all the cottages and other staff procured towels. We were very impressed. Dinner at the Bistro was outstanding. Our only disappointment was that Patrick was off that night. We had read so much about him and as oenophiles, really looked forward to meeting him. Our room, 17, was great. Only downside was a disgusting chair and ottoman. We didn't dare to sit on it. We were surprised to find it still there as we had read about it in past reviews.
Reviews.Author: cobalt23

Reviews.Content: A beatiful hotel and location, and excellent service
Reviews.Author: simonbg

Reviews.Content: A rare find! My husband (who is a hotel manager himself) and I had a wonderful experience with the Maison de Ville, even before we stayed there - we got into New Orleans after a red-eye flight to catch a cruise ship. The hotel staff were very accomodating and happily held our luggage for us while we went out for breakfast, killing time before we could board our ship. In fact, they helped us find a restaurant that my husband remembered from a previous trip to New Orleans (The Old Coffee Pot - on the block behind the hotel).When we returned from our cruise, Patrice (at the front desk) and Albert (the bellman and great asset to the hotel!) were there again to greet us. We got in early and they did all they could to get our room ready before the usual check-in time. They offered us juice, water or coffee while we waited in the cute lobby. We talked with Brian, the concierge, who was very helpful. The courtyard (with turtles in the fountain!) is very cute and relaxing. We chose to have our (complimentary) breakfast in the courtyard each morning. The coffee was fantastic (and served in elegant little silver pots), and the fresh orange juice and warm croissants and yummy pastries were a fantastic way to start the morning.Our room (#11) was not huge, but had a fantastically comfortable and very large bed, along with a nice mini-bar, great shower and plenty of closet space. We overlooked the courtyard of the hotel and a little courtyard restaurant next door. The restaurant from time to time (during daytime hours - no disturbing noise at night or early morning) had a live jazz trio which was like our own private concert as we sat on the chairs of our balcony.Yes, the bed was comfy, the location of the hotel is super (a few doors down from Bourbon Street, in the heart of the French Quarter) and the continental breakfast and complimentary internet service in the lobby are all super, however it is truly the service at this hotel that sets it apart. We were blown away by how truly kind, accomodating and warm the staff were. They went out of their way to make us comfotable and happy. It is truly the best hotel service (next to my husband's hotel, of course!) that we have ever experienced in our many travels. When we return to New Orleans, we will certainly return to Maison de Ville. Oh, and their restaurant is AMAZING. Not cheap, but worth every penny!
Reviews.Author: LikesToTravel2006

Reviews.Content: All Was Exquisite! The room was beautifully decorated, and all staff were friendly and professional. We loved the breakfast in the courtyard! Thank you for making our first visit to New Orleans perfect! We are happy to recommend Maison De Ville to all we know.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: An Oasis of Tranquility Evocative of times past the hotel was. The clock seemed to stand still while we were there. Exactly what we needed! Jessica, Lionel, and Sandra made our stay that much more enjoyable. They are truly customer service oriented. Thanks for a memorable stay!
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Such A Romantic Setting! All members of staff greeted us in some manner in passing- very hospitable. In all our many years of staying in the city, always wanted to stay here but never did. So glad we finally have for our anniversary. We felt at home.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Great French Quarter hotel My husband and I stayed at the Maison de Ville for our 5 year anniversary. We loved the atmosphere of this French Quarter hotel. The staff was excellent and very friendly. We were first put in room 16 which was located on the street. The room was huge and beautilfully decorated. However, we could already tell at 3:00 in the afternoon that the noise from Bourbon Street would be a problem. We asked to be moved to a room located in the courtyard. The staff let us look at 2 additional rooms and chooce which one would be best for us. Our second room was a bit small, but also very nice. We both enjoyed the continental breakfast which we requested to be delivered to our room.
Reviews.Author: houkris

Reviews.Content: Maison de Ville and Restaurants Stayed at Maison de Ville Hotel in the Quarter for 3 nights and it is worth every penny. Stayed in a balcony room w/ king bed. The balcony overlooked Toulouse Street (just off of Bourbon) and it was very nice to sit out there in the afternoon, listening to jazz music and watching the people below. The bed was comfortable and the room was furnished with antiques. The bathroom was also very nice - not spectacular, but clean and more than adequate. The hotel itself is very old and in a historic building with a beautiful courtyard where they serve complimentary sherry and snacks in the late afternoon.Service was impeccable. They allowed us to check in early and to check out late on our departure date when we asked at the last minute. They even offered to print our airline boarding passes for us when we left (most places will point you to the business center and certainly won't offer). Our favorite part was the complimentary breakfast each morning which you can have brought to your room on a silver tray or enjoy it in the courtyard. A carafe of coffee, juice and several pastries and croissants, all still warm from the oven (very fresh and delicious). A great way to start the day. Overall, the hotel was very romantic and homey.Restaurants:Bella Luna - We really enjoyed this restaurant. It overlooks the Mississippi River and has huge picture windows which afford a great view. Definitely a romantic environment. We had excellent service while we were there - waiter came by to pour wine periodically and check on us but was otherwise unobtrusive. Food was very good - more nouveau creole/southern cuisine. GW Finns - known for fresh and inventive seafood dishes. The smoked oyster appetizers were to die for. The menu changes daily depending upon what fish they can get in fresh that day so it's difficult to recommend specific dishes. Our service was good but a bit overly friendly (he talked our ears off for a good 15 minutes about his hometown - it was just a bit much but better than having a rude waiter). Would recommend highly - we went early (6pm) and did not need reservations.Napoleon House - Had a casual lunch in the courtyard. Just a 1/4 muffaletta and a salad. Adequate and inexpensive. The courtyard is nice, weather permitting. Service is what I call reactive. If you are pleasant to the waiters (who tend to be older gentlemen) then you get good service. We watched a group of 4 come in and they were very obnoxious right off the bat to the waiter. When they told him they were in a hurry he basically told them that they should go elsewhere or shut up. Personally, I thought they deserved it but I'm sure they thought he was rude. Definitely stop by the old bar for a Pimm's cup.Deanies in the Quarter - Had lunch here. Food was so-so (just a po-boy, kind of hard to mess up). Problem was the service. We sat at the bar, which is very large. They had 1 bartender who was serving food and drinks to approximately 30 people at the bar alone and doing drink orders for the restaurant, which is large. It took forever to get a drink, to get our order taken, to get our food and to pay. I felt sorry for him b/c he was clearly working hard but the management needed a few more bar backs.Felix's Oyster House - We like Felix's. If you just want raw oysters and the shuck-n-jive, it's the same at felix's as it is at Acme across the street. So, why wait? Dinner in the restaurant is so-so. You're probably better off sticking with either gumbo or po-boys. I had blackened fish and it was mediocre but the twice baked potato on the side was great.Just a few bars we liked - Jean Lafitte's Blacksmith Shop, Napoleon House, Fritzel's, Molly's on the Market. These were good bars for sitting and talking and catered more to people in their late 20s and up (i.e., no loud music or frat boys puking up their hand grenades). Hope this is helpful.
Reviews.Author: fly3511

Reviews.Content: Fantastic French Quarter hotel Lovely French Quarter experience, would highly recommend. Rooms were delightful. The structure is of course quite old, but the fixtures and decor were beautiful and very well done. We stayed in cottage 1 and 7, which is where Audobon lived and worked while in New Orleans. Relaxing and well kept courtyard in between the two cottages, with fountain on the wall etc. The staff were absolutely first class. One of the bellmen has been there over 15 years (not sure how long the others have been there, but could easily be the same). Location is superb, close to everything. We were there over a Saturday night, and except for a couple of muscle cars around midnight, did not hear a thing, would never have guessed we were only a block from Bourbon St. And why would anyone go to New Orleans on vacation and stay in a cookie cutter chain hotel?
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: A Tough-Love Review of the Maison de Ville The comments about the staff are pretty much true: they are great, except for a brief session with a rather rigid lady at the front desk, but maybe she was having a bad day. Though the bed linens were meticulous, the bed could have used a new spread and the rugs were almost worn through. Also, I dropped an ice cube on the wood floor and when I swiped across it with a towel, it yielded more than a little dirt. These things were surprising to find at a hotel of such purported high standing. However, the cleaning staff couldn't have been sweeter and the first rate concierge was personally concerned that we have a wonderful stay in New Orleans. Oh, be prepared that there will most certainly be a siting or two of cockroaches in your room and/or the courtyard. Unlike staying at the Ritz or the Windsor Court, staying at the Maison de Ville is more like staying at the home of a beloved aunt, who's getting older and can't see the dirt,bugs and tatters as easily.All being said, I would probably stay here again, because of the staff of pure love.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: The Maison de Ville, the best place to stay Having been visitors to New Orleans for over 15 years, we have always chose to stay at different hotels each trip, as a way of making each trip unique. After staying at this facility, we have decided to alter that plan. The exemplary service from the staff has brought us to the decision that whenever we are in New Orleans, we will only stay at the Hotel Maison de Ville.In our travels around the world, we have had the chance to stay in everything from Five Star Hotels to Bed and Breakfast Inns. The great professionalism, attention to detail, and customer focused interaction made our experience in that facility a great joy. Each member of the staff clearly made every effort possible to ensure that whatever we needed, it was done. Their empathy and warmth made each encounter a pleasant experience.It seemed that every member of the staff had the goal of making our stay enjoyable.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Loved it! Absolutely wonderful stay. The hotel, room and courtyard were filled with charm. Yes, the rooms are small but are so rich with character and quiet...we were very pleased. The staff is extremely helpful and accomodating. My husband and I would most certainly book again. One note...bring a hair dryer.
Reviews.Author: marlenenh

Reviews.Content: Loved Our Stay We loved our stay here at the Maison De Ville! This was our first trip to New Orleans and we wanted to stay somewhere that captured our romantic notions of what the city would have to offer- this was perfect. Linda made our stay even better- with her helpful and pleasant demeanor and her wonderful knowledge of the area, she really made everything about our visit even better!
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: what a find We just returned from Jazzfest and 4 days at Maison deVille. What a wonderful place. The location is perfect, a block off Bourbon St. so everything is within walking distance The courtyard rooms are, nonetheless, completely quiet(except for lovely jazz drifting in from the adjoining courtyard of Two Sisters), notwithstanding the proximity to the action. Our room was small, but nicely appointed. the lobby and courtyard are beautiful and comfortable. The true delight of this hotel is the staff, from top to bottom. We felt absolutely pampered in every way. Breakfast in the courtyard with a rose and a smile. No effort was too much to make our stay comfortable. In particular, Brian Giglio, the head concierge, was a fountain of knowledge, assistance in reservations and directions and unfailing good cheer. Maison deVille is a gem.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Superb Ambiance / Really Old School New Orleans We just returned from Maison De Ville, and I'm enthused enough to take the time to review. We stayed in the Audobon Cottages. It is quiet there....really, really quiet; however, you are only a short block from all the nightlife and fun. Everything is within walking distance. We even had our own ghost! The gardens supply such melodious scents that they are almost intoxicating....(as if you need more of that in New Orleans).... and the pool is the oldest in the Big Easy. Complimentary breakfast comes in your own private court yard on silver trays.....melt in your mouth pastries and that good southern coffee. However, *most important* is the attitude of the staff and they are outstanding. No one seems to be able to do enough to take care of your slightest wish, and they so with grace. Our deepest thanks to all of you: Brian, Patrice, Vickie, I hate to name names because I didn't encounter anyone who didn't go the extra mile from the bell men to the housekkeepers. There is an endless supply of anything you need from towels to ice to glasses in the clean, well kept unique cottages. This is *the* place in New Orleans, and I've stayed lots of places. If you want art, antiques, privacy, style, grace and super staff you've found the hotel. Small enough to care...discreet enough to not seem overpowering. Can't wait to come back!! True Southern Charm at its finest.
Reviews.Author: london6565

Reviews.Content: All The Staff Were Wonderful Jerome in particular was a real sweetheart! Thank you for helping make our 25th Anniversary so special. We will be back!
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Perfect romantic getaway. We stayed in the cottages and my husband proposed on the trip. Thecottages were charming + perfect to house my family and well wishers. Staff is caring and genteel, just as you would expectfrom an hospitable Southern city. Highly recommended.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Wonderful Hotel Staff was great! Brian had lots of info that was very helpful.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Super Hotel Everyone was very helpful. Sandra our maid was great! Brian at the front desk and another young lady were always super helpful. This was truly a superior experience for us.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Totally over-prized and over-rated. Will not stay there again1 I stayed at this hotel and I must admit that I am very surprised about the very high ratings and reviews this hotel is getting. Besides having a great concierge in Brian, a helpful staff and a beautiful courtyard, this hotel has by far to many flaws to grant a top 20 twenty rating on this site.The rooms are very small and do not even earn a 3 star rating. The room rates for this hotel are over prized. The restaurant, which is part of this hotel, is also not of the high quality the reviews promise, as our dinner was extremly disappointing and over prized. In addition we overheard other guests as well complaining.In conclusion I like to state that at least in my opinion this hotel and restaurant does not earn the high ratings it received from Fodors and Frommers, especially if you consider the high prices.The next time I will visit New Orleans I will definately stay at another hotel, but not at the Hotel Maison de Ville!
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Easy Choice in the Big Easy After spending much time reviewing hotels in the quarter, I chose the Maison de Ville as the place we would stay. The hotel was small and quaint, the service was extraordinary. Our room #7 was small, but from our balcony it opened up to a beautiful brick courtyard that also over looked another courtyard where you could hear live jazz music. The entire staff was very friendly and made sure that a person who stays at their hotel, leaves wanting to return. Rommel was especially helpful. Some of the bigger hotels may have more to offer as far as room size, pool and spa. But if you're looking for charm, look no further. The Maison de Ville is an easy choice!
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: 24yr Commited Guest Concierge Brian Giglio is the most attentive and professional employee. His overall helpfulness makes him an extremely important asset to the hotel. Room related problems...room did not have pen and paper when we arrived, used wash cloth left on shower head one day and no bath soap one day-3 day stay.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Memorable Stay Our stay was made memorable by Brian, Albert, the terrific front desk staff, Sandra and Dondrell. As always- the restaurant was special- with thanks to Greg and Patrick!
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Pleasant and Helpful Staff Everyone was very pleasant and helpful. A special tip of the hat to Brian Giglio, the concierge, for taking the time to give us some good local tips. A very nice stay indeed.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Assistance Above  Assistance of Romell above and beyond as well as that of Patrice. Each was work attentive of our concerns and needs.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: The Service Was Extraordinary Brian, Jessica, Brian, Holly, Stacy, Romell, in fact everyone was wonderful-accomodating our requests and making us feel at home. The service was extraordinary in all respects. We'd have liked the curtains to close fully and a bit hotter water, but we'll stay here again on our next visit.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: You Saved Our Vacation!!! My Husband and I recently went to New Orleans for our Anniversary. We checked into a hotel that I had found online. It was awful (small, dirty, cold, and furnished with garbage) and we began to panic. We decided that we absolutely could not stay there, so we began to walk around the Quarter to see if we could find anything available. Luckily, the first place we found was Maison De Ville. My Husband told Brian a brief version of what had happened and everyone sprang into action. We were a bit distraught at the time and Brian and the staff treated us like we were family. Unfortunatley, we were committed to at least one night in the other hotel (named after a President), but Brian assured us that everything would be ready for us in the morning. We didn't even shower in our other room, we simply awakened and headed to Maison De Ville. We arrived earlier than regular check-in, but they said that everything was ready. Room #3...My Gosh, it is beautiful. There was even a beautiful, hand written card welcoming us. Throughout our entire stay, everything was PERFECT. Brian and the staff were so helpful with any questions we had, tour info, points of interest, etc. The entire hotel is incredibly beautiful and the history is amazing.We will be back every year.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Great Staff! From Brian, Jessica and everyone at the front desk to the housekeeping staff at the Audubon Cottages where we stayed, we could not have received better, kinder and warmer care. The hotel and grounds are lovely.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Everyone Was Kind and Hospitable Brian was instrumental in making our stay fabulous. Also, Jeff was exemplary as well as Albert. Everyone was very kind and hospitable. We love it. We also enjoyed the Bistro! As for improvements, better lighting in the bathroom and the addition of a full length mirror would be nice.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Wonderful Staff Your staff is wonderful. They are friendly and always helful. We will be back and hope to try your cottages next. We are recommending your hotel to friends and family.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Small Rooms, But Otherwise Great I don't know his name, but the gentleman who did the morning service at the front desk was extremely friendly and efficient. The only criticism would be that the rooms are a little small, but otherwise great.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Helpful  Brian was very helpful in making reservations and recommendations. The bellman was friendly and attentive.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: good location, room needed work The location is great and staff was friendly and helpful. But for the price I was disapointed in the room we had. It was clean but run down and the first night I had to do battle with a big roach. But it is the south and those things happen. Next time I will book somewhere else. The new Wyndam looked very nice and is in the same area.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Our stay was perfect   showReview(2502602, 'full');
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Helpful staff   showReview(2490101, 'full');
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Charming    showReview(2459285, 'full');
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Audubon Cottages are fabulous!   showReview(2448170, 'full');
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: First rate   showReview(2423139, 'full');
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Second stay   showReview(2423133, 'full');
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Great Location, Staff and Courtyard BUT....   showReview(1791805, 'full');
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: The BIG EASY became the BIG DISAPPOINTMENT....   showReview(852894, 'full');
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Secret Garden!   showReview(747457, 'full');
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Small Luxury Hotel in New Orleans   showReview(613397, 'full');
Reviews.Author: lass=
